review.title: Subsumptive reflection in SNOMED CT: a large description logic-based terminology for diagnosis
review.abstract: Description logic (DL) based biomedical terminology (SNOMED CT) is used routinely in medical practice. However, diagnostic inference using such terminology is precluded by its complexity. Here we propose a model that simplifies these inferential components. We propose three concepts that classify clinical features and examined their effect on inference using SNOMED CT. We used PAIRS (Physician Assistant Artificial Intelligence Reference System) database (1964 findings for 485 disorders, 18 397 disease feature links) for our analysis. We also use a 50-million medical word corpus for estimating the vectors of disease-feature links. Our major results are 10% of finding-disorder links are concomitant in both assertion and negation where as 90% are either concomitant in assertion or negation. Logical implications of PAIRS data on SNOMED CT include 70% of the links do not share any common system while 18% share organ and 12% share both system and organ. Applications of these principles for inference are discussed and suggestions are made for deriving a diagnostic process using SNOMED CT. Limitations of these processes and suggestions for improvements are also discussed.

metadata.title: Subsumptive reflection in SNOMED CT: a large description logic-based terminology for diagnosis

sections.text: For our analysis, we propose the PAIRS (Physician Assistant Artificial Intelligence Reference System) database (1964 findings for 485 disorders, 18,397 disease trait links). We also use a 50 million medical word corpus to estimate the vectors of disease trait links. Our key findings are that 10% of the links between diagnosis and disorder have a concomitant appearance in both assertion and denial, with 90% being associated with either assertion or denial. The logical implications of the PAIRS data on SNOMED CT include 70% of the links that do not share a common system, while 18% share both the organ and the organ.

sections.heading: 2.1 Logical implication vs description logic in SNOMED CT
sections.text: Logical implication or co-extension is an ontological concept used for truth assessment.10 It works in five steps: a). Counter correlative, b) correlated substratum, c) adjunct limiting scope of correlated substratum, and e) relation between adjuncts in a and d. In the SNOMED-CT context, the steps would be: a). There is no heart attack, b) chest pain, c) coronary heart disease, d) coronary angiograms, e) whenever there is a heart attack. These relationships can be traced back through parent-child classes in SNOMED CT. Such a process, also known as logical implication, helps to draw conclusions in the description of logical terminologies. Entities in a class share characteristics of their parents. Since all classes inherit characteristics of their parents and some parents have, AIDS may have a reason that a child may have a limited extent of parental illness.

sections.heading: 2.2 Dataset preparation
sections.text: All diseases and characteristics are identified by SNOMED CT unique ID. Characteristics are classified as one of the categories: a) concomitant in assertion and denial, b) concomitant in assertion alone c) concomitant in denial alone. Transitive closure table is used to determine parents and their relationships and root classes: body structure, disorder, observable unit, finding, physical force, physical object, organism, process, product, situation, substance or value.

sections.heading: 2.3 Finding of weights for features given disease
sections.text: If the presence of a feature confirms the disease and its absence negates the disease: it is defined as a co-occurrence in both assertion and denial; for example, a ventricular biopsy could confirm or deny cardiomyopathy as a diagnosis; if a feature of a disease is present, it could indicate the disease, but its absence could not exclude the disease: it is only defined as a co-occurrence in assertion; examples include dyspnea in congestive heart failure; likewise, the absence of a feature could indicate a disease, but its presence does not exclude the disease; examples include the absence of deep tendon reflexes in upper motor neuron lesions; higher preference is given to those who accompany both the claim and the denial; lower but equal preference is given to those who have only one claim or negation.

sections.heading: 2.4 Vectors of features and diseases
sections.text: Each vector represents the syntactic and semantic meaning of a word. We use these vectors to find the weight of characteristics of certain diseases. If a characteristic and a certain disease have small differences in their vectors, then they are closely related. In contrast, characteristics and diseases in their vectors are very different. A high preference is given to those who are closely related. A low preference is given to those who have large differences. If a characteristic and a certain disease have an intermediate difference in their vector, they are preferred between the last two categories.

sections.heading: 2.5 Allocation of weights to features given disease
sections.text: The preferences described here are used to weight disease characteristics in ranges from 0.09 to 0.81. Estimation is made in 3 steps: a). The preferences of disease characteristics are classified in tandem as described in Figures 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 (see Figure 3). b) The preferences of the characteristics that show the highest overall preference are classified as 0.81. The preferences of the characteristics that show the highest preference are indicated as 2.1 and 2.2, but as low as 2.3. Similar allocations are made for ranges from 0.36 to 0.54 and 0.09 to 0.27. Weight distribution in PAIRS is as shown in Figure 4. The large number of disease characteristics is in the range from 0.09 to 0.27 and only a few in the range from 0.54 to 0.81. This indicates that there are fewer confirmatory findings for diseases.

sections.heading: 2.6 Diagnostic decision support engine
sections.text: The DDS engine is based on the variation method described 6 and is hosted on the web at www.ai-med.inge. A Natural Language Processor is developed using the SNOMED-CT algorithm and word marks, and its indexes are stored in a database. Transitive closure tables are used to find relationships to features and their synonyms from the PAIRS database for display. The application uses either text or XML files for diagnosis, and the diagnostic engine runs to generate lower limits and a transformation process to generate diagnostic possibilities. The 20 best options are presented in the form of infections, neoplasia, connective tissue disorders, or others.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Quantitative analysis: weights for feature given disease in PAIRS
sections.text: The distribution of weights (0.09 to 0.81) in the PAIRS data is derived from Figure 4. The data is obtained by a three-step process as described in Figure 3. A large number of features (11,000) have weights in the range of 0.09 to 0.36, with a small number (1,000) of them having weights in the range of 0.63 to 0.81, indicating that there are fewer corroborative findings for diseases. A large number of features (16,569) are associated with assertion or denial. A small number of features (1828) are associated with assertion and denial (Figure 3). Logically, accompanying features are expected to be corroborating in assertion and denial, corresponding to a smaller number of features in the range of 0.63 to 0.81, as indicated and shown in Figure 4. Also, a large number of features in assertion or denial are expected to have a higher number of features in the range of 0.09 to 0.36 to 0.54, and in the range of 0.54 to 0.36 weights, as indicated in Figure 4.

sections.heading: 3.2 Quantitative analysis: estimation of weights using SNOMED CT
sections.text: The hierarchy of the SNOMED-CT class is complex, and its multiple inheritances and over-use of Is-A type relationships preclude reasoning by descriptive logic 11. We are able to assign weight by introducing assertions and / or negations as a class for disease-related traits. Coupled with logical implications (or co-extensions) of disease-related traits, they give a hierarchical preference for weights. As shown in Figure 3, a large number of disease-related traits (13,031) do not share a system or organ, while a small number of them (2288) share the same system. Some disease-related traits (3078) share the same system, but no organ.

sections.heading: 3.3 Qualitative analysis: estimation of weights in PAIRS using SNOMED CT
sections.text: PAIRS data use these weights in their DDS. Therefore, large-scale descriptive logic-based SNOMED CT terminologies can be used to arrive at conclusions such as diagnoses. As the principles proposed here are simple, they can be easily integrated into the existing architecture of any terminology.

sections.heading: 3.4 Evaluation of PAIRS
sections.text: We used clinical cases of MGH in the New England Journal of Medicine to evaluate PAIRS. We are looking for the possibility of a diagnosis that appears in the top 20 of PAIRS diagnoses, and the actual diagnosis appears in 28 out of 30 cases in the top 20. Results are available at http: / / www.ai-med.in / cases / Further diagnostic evaluations of PAIRS are in progress.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text: SNOMED CT is a comprehensive terminology based on descriptive logic that has been developed since 1965. It gathers decades of knowledge from several thousand physicians around the world. Despite this enormous effort, there are shortcomings with regard to conclusions, and by introducing new inference classes in it, one can improve their performance. We used PAIRS as an example to show how to use SNOMED CT to assign weights to characteristics of certain disease. These weights are further used to make a diagnosis in DDS.Aristotelian logic uses 3 terms (main term, secondary term and middle term) to derive conclusions. A similar theory is proposed in Indian logic, and a comprehensive coverage of perception and conclusions has been available for over 5 millennia in the Sanskrit literature. Modern logic finds shortcomings in Aristotelian logic and several new theories on cause or conclusion.
